content.statement: vascular:diagnostics:dx-003-pulse-exam is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Diagnostics that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding vascular:diagnostics:dx-003-pulse-exam helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of vascular:diagnostics:dx-003-pulse-exam include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of vascular:diagnostics:dx-003-pulse-exam.

upper_extremity.radial: Lateral volar wrist, between radial styloid and FCR
upper_extremity.ulnar: Medial volar wrist, lateral to FCU
upper_extremity.brachial: Medial antecubital fossa, between biceps tendon and medial epicondyle
upper_extremity.axillary: Lateral chest wall, behind pectoralis major

lower_extremity.femoral: Below inguinal ligament, midpoint between ASIS and pubic symphysis
lower_extremity.popliteal: Popliteal fossa, knee flexed 30 degrees, fingers curl around tibia
lower_extremity.dorsalis_pedis: Dorsum of foot, lateral to extensor hallucis longus

neck.carotid: Anterior border of sternocleidomastoid at cricoid level

grading_system.4+: Bounding - may indicate aneurysm or hyperdynamic state

technique.palpation: Use fingertips (not thumb - has own pulse)

handheld_doppler.technique: Apply gel, hold probe at 45-60 degrees to vessel
handheld_doppler.triphasic: Normal - sharp upstroke, brief reversal, forward flow

adjuncts.pallor_elevation: Buerger test - pallor with elevation, rubor with dependency

normal_variants.prominent_peroneal: May be dominant in some individuals

definition.@value: Systematic palpation and grading of peripheral arterial pulses at standardized anatomic locations to assess vascular perfusion and localize arterial occlusive disease.

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Locate and palpate all major peripheral pulses
Integrate findings to localize arterial disease
clinical_pearls: Absent dorsalis pedis is normal variant in 5-10% - always check posterior tibial
Use fingertips, NOT thumb (thumb has its own pulse)
Popliteal pulse is deep - flex knee, curl fingers around tibia
Triphasic Doppler = normal; monophasic = severe disease
Palpable pulse does NOT exclude significant stenosis - check Doppler waveform
Compare bilaterally - asymmetry is more informative than absolute findings

medicalCode.description: Non-invasive physiologic studies of upper or lower extremity arteries
